DAC364C3C21343068E7D0E033FB4EBBB.description: Examine the impact of faith-motivated service and communal endeavors on individuals and communities.

8D68526D2FE747E6B34B193930D1F724.description: Explain how the planned Christian Action Project, rally and/or retreat might affect one's life and faith development.

D8049BFA84B54978A58FDA753969115B.description: Create, in collaboration with one's peers and teacher, a plan for participation in a Christian Action Project, rally and/or retreat.

AB986A4B480A44D2B419419CA0269CD5.description: Describe how one's experience in a Christian Action Project, rally and/or retreat affects one's life and understanding of the Catholic faith.

2D5BCC0F99384A93A13D6C06FC5A0AC6.description: Express how varying religious expression within the rites of Catholicism are complementary rather than contradictory (e.g., sacramental rituals, expressions of Marian devotion or prayers through the communion of saints).

22B0D20310234185BDAD29508C26E300.description: Give examples to show the difference between: Apostolic or Holy Tradition (e.g., Marian devotion, writings of Church authorities, hierarchy of the Church built on the witness of Peter, the apostles and their successors), ecclesial traditions (e.g., language of the mass, Ukrainian traditions within the Byzantine rite, First Nations and Metis smudging and music in Catholic liturgy, Filipino Good Friday cultural practices, Greek Orthodox celebrations).

2854AD55FBA64880AD6F90AB0950288F.description: Represent the concept of multiple traditions but one faith.

10041B1693844ED1A08930C30E1F6ACE.description: Identify and discuss key characteristics of the seven rites of the Catholic Church (i.e., Latin, Byzantine, Alexandrian, Syriac, Armenian, Maronite, and Chaldean).

970C614755254D23B519275F83807171.description: Investigate how diverse Catholic rites are varying expressions of the same faith.

D197972474EB4F96AD61D02DCA1D38C4.description: Discuss challenges and benefits of leading a healthy lifestyle involving both virtual and real world experiences.

4DD866446E81411F98F63F87384663C9.description: Examine how digital behaviour can develop, sustain, or harm relationships (e.g., chat rooms, text messaging, social media, online tutorials).

44279931DB264BA39E6978C18D9AAB3A.description: Describe personal, social and legal consequences of inappropriate online behaviour and content (e.g., spreading inaccurate information and rumours, cyberbullying, texting while driving, sexting, pornography, child exploitation).

AC80F6CD79D5444BBF9EAF835A3A5DF4.description: Review common practices and assess personal behaviours in digital environments (e.g., downloading video, posting images of others) considering morality and legality.

35F091DA84CE4BE08EF8B8B07A34A87A.description: Co-create a class 'responsible use policy' for digital behaviour, using Ribble's nine elements, that reflects Catholic values (e.g., social teachings, human dignity, communion of people, Ten Commandments, Beatitudes, good Samaritan).

CD8C7BAE643342408E22AB5BB2AD1D38.description: Assess benefits, risks and responsibilities of digital citizenship from a Catholic perspective.

B49F4F339D4C4CA5B9DB09BB955CABBE.description: Discuss the meaning, value and power of modesty in contemporary society.

F23FE2F6F56A48248F04336E01485373.description: Discuss effects of attitudes and actions towards people based on gender, sexuality or sexual activity (e.g., double standards, rumours, judgements, stereotypes, supports, affirmations).

A792FACCB97D4D5CB7674418A631CAD5.description: Describe various types of birth avoidance (e.g., contraceptives, sterilization, abortifacients, abortion) and control (e.g., Natural Family Planning) in terms of their: method of use and reliability, ethics and effects on individuals and society.

5AE5E4B4F7CC4E7C8220B512641B442E.description: Discuss the importance of clear personal consent in all sexual encounters and the influence of popular culture terminology within this discussion (e.g., cultural of sexual consent, no means no, silence is not consent, rape culture).

91CD733BDAA543E6A2A30B8243D23B21.description: Express personal views about romantic relationships and dating considering influences such as peer pressure and support, emotional complexity, diverse societal and religious messages.

FC88EE4BAA0C46288E1F0D907AA97F4D.description: Explain chastity from a Catholic perspective.

A0D3D746066F430EBBF2508FDF408DD2.description: Describe Catholic teachings and moral implications of the two purposes of sex (i.e., the unitive and loving purpose and being open to the possibility of procreation).

B2DEE7C2050B4EB5AD6605207510138D.description: Discuss the following concepts of Saint Pope John Paul II's theology of the body: sex as an expression of love and a gift from God (e.g., the sacred nature or fundamental 'goodness' of sex), the body expressing the person (e.g., sex is a part of one's body language), differentiating love from lust.

15F4ECE55A5E458291692A1D712E173C.description: Examine personal and societal impacts and ethical perspectives surrounding chastity, abstinence and sexual activity.

80C5021C5B2E470E8AAD20558AE8D20F.description: Analyze how concepts such as peace, love, hope, faithful obedience and truth apply to the development of a society with a culture of life (e.g., Evangelium Vitae).

7718FFEBC24947D99BA15228DCD9EBDB.description: Provide examples and implications of the ethical concept of 'slippery slope' (e.g., euthanasia).

ABF7D1F241914EA79BC958E2EC032BCC.description: Examine ways that science can deepen understanding within pro-life debates.

7EF2985FB3B7442AA1F46C637F232DDB.description: Discuss ways of building a culture that values the dignity of life (e.g., demonstrating compassion and empathy for others).

A5D6228B929F4A3BB6C98FEF7D46789D.description: Describe examples of legality and morality coming into conflict (e.g., child labour laws, sanctioned military action, medical abortion or doctor-assisted suicide, capital punishment).

625977B37B4A4D91AA2C1C895824EAD7.description: Describe how individuals and communities believing in inherent human dignity can take action to support, for example: people affected by pregnancy, people with disabilities, perpetrators of crime. those who are struggling with ethical decisions or regret, people who are sick or suffering, other marginalized groups and individuals.

C1EB12C7884F44E6BE64207F984E1CD9.description: Investigate the concept of a pastoral approach and discuss its value in supporting others (e.g., Evangelium Vitae â€“ 99, Catholic Christian Outreach movement).

F3644D0AA00545D9A799FEE0F7EFF9A6.description: Describe the importance of forgiveness for oneself and others in building a society that places emphasis on reconciliation rather than judgement.

453FD84E347243DF80399D3FD5C9C982.description: Generate inquiry questions considering the scope of a pro-life stance (e.g., How is the "culture of life" described by Saint Pope John Paul II relevant to daily living? How can a pro-life stance deepen understanding of issues related to capital punishment, gender equality and palliative care?).

3123B49FD11445E29F86E0859ED7D723.description: Investigate what it means to be pro-life and describe the benefits and challenges of building a society that values the dignity of life.

EE7A8DB1553A4B45A6DA3B0956A5364B.description: Investigate commonalities among Christianity, Judaism and Islam beginning with Abraham and his two sons Isaac and Ishmael.

F8B3C29B31A94CC08ED98AB94CD9A4EF.description: Provide examples of how the following can affect dialogue: striving for unity versus uniformity, engaging to learn versus indifference or stereotyping, intending to collaborate versus to convert.

045E0BFB933D4F3682C8327635F555C1.description: Describe the importance of expressing and holding true to one's beliefs and identity when engaging in dialogue (e.g., ecumenical, interfaith, non-religious).

105ED00D1A4544E3803F58FB94761C1E.description: Discuss the relevance of the Prayer of St. Francis for Catholics engaging in dialogue.

E9ADCAA21D7D433FA4D67A275F270EFC.description: Describe how individuals can help develop and engage in what Pope Francis describes as a 'culture of encounter' (e.g., The Common Witness Project).

0C88E4358B174F43BB24F741AB82103C.description: Discuss factors that contribute to effective religious and spiritual dialogue such as: recognizing the dignity of the person, ethics (i.e., the search for the good), use of prayer, hospitality towards all, valuing 'right relationships'.

50DF79BC8C0A4E159FE20CBFD2C79221.description: Recognize positive and negative effects of language (e.g., spoken, written, body) on individuals and society.

66D4FAA56E584C0A8635C714B3C725B4.description: Discuss differences between ecumenical and interfaith dialogue considering, for example: ecumenical dalogue is based on a shared life in Christ and an imperative to seek unity with other Christians (e.g., Jesus prays to the Father in John 17:11-21 that his disciples become one), the goal of interfaith dialogue is not unity, but overcoming misunderstandings so as to discern where people of all faith traditions can act together in pursuit of the common good, distinctions in prayer (e.g., ecumenical members praying to the same God, interfaith members coming together to pray according to their own traditions).

5A9081FFC86748B78A5F47B20185D0B7.description: Examine how religious and spiritual dialogue can develop understanding and move faith communities towards greater unity.

272BCA1E92E244FF8DA4E0F79F4327D8.description: Distinguish the mission and recruitment methods of the Church from those of destructive cults, extremist groups, and those seeking to proselytize.

BE5F8E9A9C7F4294818CCC19376632C2.description: Examine individual responsibility to share the story of salvation (i.e., evangelize) and encourage accountability for one's actions (e.g., standing up to bullying).

E9B08AA66BC0433F9436727C804CFD4A.description: Recognize how one's daily actions reflect the five actions identified by the Canadian Conference of Catholic Bishops to support the mission of the Church (i.e., proclaim Jesus, worship Christ through the sacraments, form a communion of people, give witness to Jesus Christ, serve in the model of Jesus).

D8115DDA50064E7B917790FF94162B64.description: Express how loving acts involving the Church and her teachings (e.g., charity, education, health care, reconciliation, cultural understanding) can help unite communities locally and globally in support of the Church's mission.

C5508C6487154AFD82A252F424884DD2.description: Describe how tragic events in Church history (e.g., residential school experiences, religious wars, sexual abuse scandals) have harmed individuals, the Church and her mission.

F4AE5537F5874FB390D57D6EE04A235D.description: Describe how the Church's mission of uniting people through love is supported by models of church proposed by Cardinal Avery Dulles (i.e., institution, mystical communion, sacrament, herald, servant, community of disciples).

49DE4BE58AB5432B9FC815E0752B2147.description: Discuss personal and societal benefits of being a contributing member in Catholic and other Christian communities.

4E03BA4458D14D62B3F24FF5EB1DD765.description: Recognize individual responsibility within Catholic communities to help achieve the Church's mission and describe how students can help.

FAD52C74D91A4E3CA72128E0AC38FF20.description: Express diverse perspectives on the mission of the Church (e.g., CCC773).

D0ED75DAAEC042DB809089F85FF150D1.description: Investigate how individuals within Catholic communities can help the Church achieve her mission.

85AAD292057641DF9788CDD7FCC48BD5.description: Describe how following the five precepts of the Church listed in the Catechism of the Catholic Church can support people in the development of a personal relationship with God.

CADDC1BECC7947EBA917AAA2B70BA38B.description: Describe how destructive cults may influence those seeking a personal relationship with God (e.g., psychological coercion, providing community and meaning, charismatic attraction of a false prophet).

E88BF421250C47ACBD74B717A165D407.description: Examine personal and societal challenges to developing a personal relationship with God.

3C51B3BC61054A34B4B0454D217F0969.description: Represent the Catholic concept of the Communion of Saints.

1B7DC49B33FD43ECA973C8CA4A1D4929.description: Describe benefits of worship and prayer for individuals and communities.

9D526B3FBB5D4C5F83B45314F1CB96B2.description: Discuss diverse expressions of prayer such as: five types of prayer in the Catechism (i.e., petition, intercession, thanksgiving, blessing/adoration and praise) including commentaries on prayer types (e.g., Rev. Dr. Eileen Conway in The Common Witness Project), Catholic prayer rituals (e.g., Rosary, Novenas, forms of examination of conscience, mealtime prayers, praise and worship music and hymns, intercession of the saints), traditional First Nations prayer (e.g., smudging, use of medicine wheel, sweats, tipi teachings, Sun Dance, pipe ceremonies), infusion of traditional First Nations spiritual practices in Catholic liturgical celebrations (e.g., smudging, praying towards the four directions, using a star blanket to take up the collection), Jewish prayer rituals (e.g., Rosh Hashana blessings, the Blessing of the Sun or other natural phenomena, affixing a Mezuzah, ritual prayers for Shabbat, Chanukkah candle lighting), Muslim call to prayer (i.e., 5 daily prayers and postures), Evangelical praise and worship (e.g., through song).

9C31CAD8AC6442F587ACBDDA4037CB6D.description: Discuss the role of humility in a maturing faith and prayer life.

BC9FAEBA621E4317A4FA32C6A78A124D.description: Compare the development of a relationship with God to that of another person (e.g., communicating, spending time together).

468FDC712A674585A8FDACFCD52373A3.description: Research and construct a classroom definition for the following terms: God, Creator, Trinity, faith, spirituality, religion, sect, church, cult.

21A5E4A7970648F58BF258620D17A6CA.description: Examine the influence of a community of believers (e.g., Church, destructive cult) in the development of a personal relationship with God.

BFF645A0C5F644E78A9B43659538B283.description: Express how and why an individual would develop a personal relationship with God.

5102619188B240DE9153B335B28E58D4.description: Differentiate between Church teachings being easy to understand versus easy to live up to (e.g., lying, chastity, stealing, illegal downloading).

FF2BD731505743CB92ABB071754A6841.description: Express views about personal and societal risks of: failure to develop one's conscience, sole reliance on empirical data to form one's conscience, blind faith in a religious organization to form one's conscience.

484857E3E841444784681A8CD85375E7.description: Discuss factors that contribute to the development of conscience, such as: empirical data, reason and logic, Catholic social teachings, theological and cardinal virtues, grace, moral and ethical theories.

B8823E12ADC84099B7CB7E107415EA88.description: Investigate what the Church means by the 'primacy of the conscience' and 'the sense of the faithful'.

E0B3C01DC9B04E1A989F3984B9D4D454.description: Discuss the value and challenges of reconciliation with others and the ability to forgive oneself (e.g., living with guilt, anger, sorrow).

ACD76E5D1CBE4AC19ADDB9BB19017297.description: Describe the challenges faced when attempting to live according to high moral and ethical standards (e.g., temptation, peer pressure, personal vices, human weakness).

425ABA8FB79B4C99992EF26A57948977.description: Discuss the value of setting high standards of personal behaviour stemming from one's conscience.

F6E5EB5B8DFC4CE5BD761069707770EC.description: Propose questions for inquiry and express key principles of Catholic social teachings (e.g., life and dignity of the human person, options for the poor and vulnerable, care for God's creation, dignity of work and rights of workers).

D16B43AA404240BF95165FF0E0695BC8.description: Examine challenges and benefits of developing and living according to one's conscience.

D3E0A189434C4A73821FE83B8D418893.description: Describe the impact of forgiveness in one's life and community (e.g., Truth and Reconciliation, sexual abuse, mass shootings).

E5AA23A68DBB490F929475C94FAE1477.description: Assess the ethical and moral implications of the scriptural question: "Am I my brother's keeper?" (i.e., Gen. 4:9).

DDA203557C72466C8C3CA12BA30F9FAA.description: Reflect on one's moral development using an ethical theory or model such as: Thomas Aquinas' concept of natural law, Immanuel Kant's ethics of duty. Emmanuel Levinas' ethics of the face of the other, Lawrence Kohlberg's moral development stages, Carol Gilligan and Nel Nodding's ethic of care.

BD5CF2A2230A4597A3F6BC6F8D63278A.description: Describe how Jesus' teachings on sin and virtue can influence one's daily actions.

0A4C8C2FE0774713883A786B5CDD57D1.description: Describe how Jesus' teachings of the Beatitudes lead to virtuous living.

F29D687C3F7E4D728F43865539E2FEE9.description: Discuss the relationship between Catholic virtues and the seven capital (i.e., deadly) sins.

C991BFDB4AEA4BCB86FFE5EC3CD71C7A.description: Research the Catechism's three categories of sin (i.e., original, personal and social).

237003984A1F4CE1B1A5D0302AC85708.description: Contrast a legalistic view of sin from a relational view of sin according to Jesus' teachings.

80E4FC76408A4CBF85BF393491DA350D.description: Discuss the role of free will in relation to sin, virtue, ethics and morality.

EBE51BED07144513B30A03B81F58445F.description: Investigate Catholic perspectives on sin and virtue and consider ethical and moral implications for one's life and community.

AAEEE334F05A4599B326C568CC71C92D.description: Discuss love (e.g., family, unconditional, romantic) and its representation in society (e.g., fine art, pop culture depictions).

9E7A9031666B491AACF3FA99B43A3480.description: Discuss the importance of hope in one's prayer life during times of adversity.

5FDDA970527143E494AF9FA803DE33DC.description: Create a representation (e.g., dance, written, digital) of the difference between faithful obedience and blind obedience.

69A7758E36F242CEBDF720B890B2B984.description: Discuss benefits and challenges of loving your enemies and praying for those who persecute you (i.e., Matthew 5:44).

53583E7596754E61B826F7EFEE77BF83.description: Explain how faithful obedience, peace, love, hope and truth can help to persevere against sin.

E0690AEB7A274BD894A8A85B8BFAF9AA.description: Describe personal and societal benefits of living a life of faithful obedience, peace, love, hope and truth.

355455ACE5BC4A919C7A14565C1DD319.description: Examine how individuals, although flawed, can exemplify characteristics of: faithful obedience lived (e.g., Mary mother of Jesus, Saint Thomas More, Saint Katharine Drexel, Venerable Father Michael McGivney, Saint Ignatius of Loyola), peace lived (e.g., Saint Mother Teresa, David Shepherd and Travis Price, Joan Baez), love lived (e.g., Victoria Leigh Soto, Florence Nightingale, Saint Nicholas of Myra), hope lived (e.g., Terry Fox, Clara Hughes, Walter Dieter, Special Olympians), truth lived (e.g., Sister Nuala Kenny M.D., Dr. Josephine Lombardi, Medger Evers, Saint John Chrysostom).

81A0C5158D874BB5AD0DFC876618C330.description: Describe Jesus as a model for faithful obedience, peace, love, hope and truth.

5A8C20CD4F2C4D5491DBFCB576251970.description: Express Catholic perspectives on faithful obedience, peace, love, hope and truth within the ongoing nature of salvation history.

E1D334ED82A04DABB70593C73A1EE23E.description: Discuss responsibilities within the covenantal relationship (e.g., anointed as priest, prophet and king; stewardship; God's responsibilities to His people).

1D02F2517891445B9874D984FDB83FB6.description: Discuss Catholic understanding of good and evil and the teaching that immoral acts do not change the goodness and dignity of humanity.

3C22BF81A82D4E9B9E6D16E2DC30FD86.description: Describe ways of developing positive relationships with: God (e.g., prayer, scripture study), God's creation (e.g., sustainability), Others (e.g., demonstrating charity, acting on Truth and Reconciliation recommendations), Self (e.g., forgiveness, maintaining wellness).

536ECBCFF1944154A71FDB7E9B448A9F.description: Investigate the development and relevance to daily life of the covenantal relationship between God and humanity through stories of: the days of creation (Gen. 1:1 - 2:4a), another account of creation (Gen. 2:4b -25), the first sin and breaking of the covenant (Gen. 3), Noah and the flood (Gen. 6-9), the call and covenant of Abram (Gen. 12: 1 - 9 , Gen. 15) and Abraham, Sarah, their children and the covenant (Gen. 16 - 18:15, 21-22).

D4933B04D4BA45F888C3F9D529BE89EC.description: Describe similarities and differences among covenants, contracts, promises, alliances and treaties.

F2D2B03BA4214238B32CD5E113EBD5E7.description: Describe what is meant by Catholic bible literacy (e.g., locating scriptural passages, recognizing differences among Christian bibles, understanding Catholic interpretations of Scripture).

3DAB14C2BCB9412BBB8227173E097012.description: Examine the significance of God's covenantal relationship with humanity through the stories of: Adam and Eve, Noah and Abraham and Sarah.

8F02F9C82483439A8C6179D4F712CDA8.description: Respond to artistic concepts and representations of creation such as: Sky Woman by Shelley Niro in the Canadian Museum of History, Michelangelo's images from Genesis painted on the Sistine Chapel ceiling, calligraphy or geometric designs to convey the language and greatness of the universe in Muslim art

5113DB8DECC54BFBA099C355E3AC070F.description: Express how moments of being in awe of the wonders of the universe can enrich spiritual and religious development (e.g., inspire artistic expression, commitment to sustainability, prayer, service).

9BCFF8D3EAAD4706B5AB656A96062FBF.description: Provide personal perspectives on the following statements:: ".. science and faith are not opposed to each other, but, on the contrary, need and complete each other" (Saint Pope John Paul II, 2001)., Science without religion is lame, religion without science is blind" (Albert Einstein, 1941)., Western scientists tell us that we are born of the union of male and female, but we know that only relates to our material selves" (Elder Noel Starblanket, 2001).

C433BBAFF749468F982D964AB64C082C.description: Describe the difference between contextual and literal approaches to Scripture and the implications for one's faith.

FFD8BC9542554474B45BB00063F69E7A.description: Describe how Catholic teachings, scientific evidence and other perspectives influence one's faith and beliefs about the origin and evolution of life (e.g., Aquinas' five proofs, Trinity, Big Bang, theory of evolution, Turtle Island, New Atheism).

9CA7F0082AB34C34BB2215AC91E6E1C9.description: Describe similarities and differences in various creation accounts, stories and theories including First Nations teachings (e.g., Genesis, cultural teachings about how the earth and life were formed, scientific theory of evolution).

2FBF1A10D1A64F81B72D9F5A97717501.description: Conduct an inquiry into questions about the origins of the universe and humanity (e.g., Where did we come from? Why are we here?).

9C40BD55ED344ED4A415FAECF0DAC4C4.description: Examine how science and religion influence understanding of creation and faith formation.
